questions.question:
Question 1: A 55-year-old chronic alcoholic presents with complaints of recurrent epigastric pain, 
progressive weight loss, and foul-smelling diarrhoea for the past 6 months. CT scan reveals 
pancreatic calcification and dilatation of the main pancreatic duct. Which of the following 
statements is false about his condition?

options.a: It is more common in males
options.c: Abdominal pain is the most common symptom
options.d: Pain increases as destruction of the pancreas progresses

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of chronic pancreatitis. Pain decreases or disappears as 
the destruction of the pancreas progress. This is called a burned-out pancreas. This correlates with 
the progression of disease from a mild or moderate stage to severe destruction of the pancreas. Chronic pancreatitis is a progressive inflammatory disease in which there is an irreversible 
destruction of pancreatic tissue. It is more common in males, with a male: female ratio of 4:1.

questions.question: Question 2: What is the most common cause of chronic pancreatitis?
questions.explanation:
836 
Sold by @itachibot Alcohol consumption is the most common cause of chronic pancreatitis, accounting for 60–70% 
of the cases. Smoking increases the risk of alcohol-induced chronic pancreatitis. Cystic fibrosis is the most common cause of chronic pancreatitis in the pediatric age group. Other causes of chronic pancreatitis include: • Pancreatic divisum • Annular pancreas • Hyperlipidemia • Hypercalcemia • Hyperparathyroidism • Chronic duct obstruction • Autoimmune pancreatitis • Cystic fibrosis • Tropical pancreatitis • Hereditary pancreatitis

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following is not a part of the TIGAR-O classification?
questions.explanation:
The T in the TIGAR-O classification stands for toxic-metabolic, not trauma. The TIGAR-O classification system is an etiological approach to classify chronic pancreatitis and 
pancreatic exocrine insufficiency.

questions.question:
Question 4: A young patient with recurrent abdominal pain and pancreatic calcification was found to have 
a mutation in SPINK1. Which of the following statements is false about this condition? 828 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: Associated with high incidence of diabetes mellitus.
options.b: It can be distinguished from chronic alcoholic pancreatitis histologically.
options.c: Cassava ingestion is an etiological factor.

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario of chronic pancreatitis with SPINK1 mutation is suggestive of tropical 
pancreatitis (nutritional pancreatitis). Tropical pancreatitis is histologically indistinguishable from 
chronic alcoholic pancreatitis. Normally, if trypsinogen does become prematurely activated within the pancreas, it is inhibited by 
SPINK1 and then gets destroyed. A loss-of-function mutation in SPINK1 affects this process and 
predisposes to tropical pancreatitis. Tropical pancreatitis is a form of idiopathic pancreatitis that begins at a young age and is usually 
seen in Indonesia, southern India (Kerala), and tropical Africa. It is associated with a high 
incidence of diabetes mellitus (a brittle form of pancreatogenic diabetes) and stone 
formation. Causes of chronic tropical pancreatitis include: • Malnutrition • Ingestion of cyanogenic glycosides in cassava • Exposure to hydrocarbons released from kerosene or paraffin lamps 837 
Sold by @itachibot Tropical pancreatitis is histologically indistinguishable from chronic alcoholic pancreatitis.

questions.question: Question 5: Hereditary chronic pancreatitis is caused by the mutation of:
questions.explanation:
Hereditary chronic pancreatitis is caused by the mutation of PRSS1 (protease serine 1). Hereditary pancreatitis is an autosomal dominant disorder, associated with a gain-of-function 
mutation in the cationic trypsinogen gene (PRSS1) on chromosome 7q. This leads to 
intrapancreatic activation of trypsinogen and the production of the degradation-resistant form of 
trypsin. PRSS1 mutation accounts for about two-thirds of cases of hereditary pancreatitis. There is an 
increased risk of developing pancreatic cancer, particularly if the patient smokes tobacco. Option B: Cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene is located on the 
long arm of chromosome 7, and it regulates bicarbonate and chloride concentrations in 
respiratory and pancreatic secretions. • Homozygous CFTR mutations result in cystic fibrosis • Heterozygous mild CFTR mutations predispose to pancreatic exocrine insufficiency and chronic 
pancreatitis Options C and D: Serine peptidase inhibitor Kazal type 1 (SPINK1) or pancreatic secretory trypsin 
inhibitor (PSTI) is associated with tropical calcific pancreatitis as well idiopathic chronic 
pancreatitis.

questions.question:
Question 6: A 35-year-old diabetic patient presented with complaints of recurrent abdominal pain and 
weight loss. Investigations showed features suggestive of obstructive jaundice and MRI 
revealed the following abnormality. All of the statements are true regarding the given 
condition except:

options.a: It is likely to resolve spontaneously
options.c: Serum IgG4 is elevated in type 2
options.d: Corticosteroids are the treatment of choice

questions.explanation:
The clinical features and characteristic sausage-shaped appearance of the pancreas on the T2 
weighted image are diagnostic of autoimmune pancreatitis (AIP). Serum IgG4 is normal in type 2 
AIP. It is elevated in type 1 AIP. Autoimmune pancreatitis (AIP) is a chronic inflammatory disorder of the pancreas. Patients 
present with features of obstructive jaundice, weight loss, and mild abdominal pain. CT scan or MRI showing a diffuse enlarged, sausage-shaped pancreas is characteristic of 
autoimmune pancreatitis. Serum IgG4 level is considered the best serological marker for AIP. Most of the cases resolve spontaneously. However, corticosteroid therapy is the treatment of 
choice as it causes increased remission of AIP. Also, AIP is associated with gastric ulcer formation 
as there are abundant IgG4 levels. Hence NSAIDs are not part of the management. They are of two types: Features

questions.question: Question 7: The Rosemont criteria for the diagnosis of chronic pancreatitis is based on:
questions.explanation:
Rosemont’s criteria for the diagnosis of chronic pancreatitis is based on endoscopic 
ultrasonographic (EUS) findings.

questions.question:
Question 8: Which of the following diagnostic tests have the highest sensitivity and specificity to diagnose 
chronic pancreatitis?
questions.explanation:
The diagnostic test with the best sensitivity and specificity for chronic pancreatitis is the secretin 
test. Secretin is a hormone secreted by the small intestines. It normally stimulates the pancreas to 
secrete a fluid with a high concentration of bicarbonate. Secretin stimulation test is a test that 
measures the ability of the pancreas to respond to secretin. In order to perform the test, a tube is passed into the duodenum. Secretin is administered 
intravenously and the contents of the duodenal secretions are aspirated and analyzed over a 
period of about 2 hours. The test becomes abnormal when  60% of the pancreatic exocrine 
function has been lost. This usually correlates well with the onset of chronic abdominal pain. Other investigations to diagnose chronic pancreatitis: Pancreatic calcifications can be seen on abdominal X-rays. Endoscopic ultrasound showing the presence of four or more of these following features is highly 
suggestive of chronic pancreatitis: • Presence of stones • Visible side branches • Cysts • Lobularity • An irregular main pancreatic duct • Hyperechoic foci and strands 839 
Sold by @itachibot • Dilatation of the main pancreatic duct • Hyperechoic margins of the main pancreatic duct An abdominal CT scan is the initial modality of choice for diagnosing chronic pancreatitis. CT or 
MRI scan will show the outline of the gland, the main area of damage, and the possibilities for 
surgical correction. The investigation of choice for chronic pancreatitis is MRCP with secretin stimulation. ERCP is 
the gold-standard investigation. They help in identifying the presence of biliary obstruction and 
the state of the pancreatic duct.

questions.question:
Question 10: A 65-year-old man who had multiple episodes of pancreatitis presented with a history of mild 
epigastric pain and the presence of foul-smelling greasy stools for the past 5 months. MRCP 
showed the presence of a chain of lake appearance in the pancreas. What is the most likely 
diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
840 
Sold by @itachibot The chain of lakes appearance on pancreatography (ERCP or MRCP) is diagnostic of chronic 
pancreatitis. In chronic pancreatitis, there are multiple strictures and stones in the pancreatic duct. This leads 
to the alternate stenosis and dilatation of the pancreatic duct leading to the chain of lakes 
appearance.

questions.question: Question 11: A patient with chronic pancreatitis can develop all of the following complications, except:
questions.explanation:
Renal artery stenosis and insulinoma are not complications of chronic pancreatitis. Complications of chronic pancreatitis: Intrapancreatic complications: • Pseudocysts • Duodenal or gastric obstruction • Thrombosis of splenic vein • Abscess • Perforation • Erosion into the visceral artery • Inflammatory mass in the head of the pancreas • Bile duct stenosis • Portal vein thrombosis • Duodenal obstruction • Duct strictures and/or stones • Ductal hypertension and dilatation • Pancreatic carcinoma Extrapancreatic complications: • Pancreatic duct leak with ascites or fistula • Pseudocyst extension beyond lesser sac into mediastinum, retroperitoneum, lateral pericolic 
spaces, pelvis, or adjacent viscera

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following statements is false about the complications of chronic pancreatitis?

options.a: All the complications of acute pancreatitis can occur in patients with chronic pancreatitis.
options.c: Calcium oxalate is the most common type of stone in chronic pancreatitis.
options.d: At least 90% of acinar cells should be lost before malabsorption symptoms manifest.

questions.explanation:
Calcium carbonate stone is the most common type of stone formed in chronic pancreatitis. Calcium and bicarbonate ions are normally present in pancreatic juice in high concentrations. 
Lithostathine is a potent inhibitor of calcium carbonate crystal formation. In alcoholics and in 
patients with alcoholic chronic pancreatitis, lithostathine expression and secretion are 
dramatically inhibited leading to calcification. 841 
Sold by @itachibot Other complications of chronic pancreatitis: • Exocrine insufficiency - At least 90% of the gland needs to be dysfunctional before 
malabsorption symptoms manifest like: • Fat-soluble vitamin deficiency • Bleeding • Osteopenia • Osteoporosis • Endocrine insufficiency - Diabetes mellitus. Exocrine insufficiency usually precedes endocrine 
insufficiency. • All the complications of acute pancreatitis can occur in patients with chronic pancreatitis.

questions.question:
Question 13: A young male patient presents with steatorrhea associated with chronic pancreatitis. A stool 
examination of the patient shows increased fecal fat and decreased fecal elastase. What is the 
mode of administration of the pancreatic enzymes in this patient?
questions.explanation:
The mode of administration of pancreatic enzymes in exocrine pancreatic insufficiency is through 
an oral route. Effects of pancreatic enzyme replacement in chronic pancreatitis: • Reverses exocrine insufficiency • Prevents secondary complications such as metabolic bone disease due to inadequate absorption 
of the fat-soluble vitamins A, D, E, and K • Reduces pain due to chronic pancreatitis Pancreatic enzyme supplementation is done with meals. Non-enteric-coated tablets are degraded 
by gastric juice and the released enzymes inhibit cholecystokinin (CCK) secretion. This, in turn, 
decreases the pancreatic secretion and thereby reduces the pain caused due to the increased 
accumulation of the secretions within the pancreatic duct. Enteric-coated tablets are not degraded in the proximal small intestine and, hence, might not be 
effective in reducing CCK secretion and relieving pain.

questions.question:
Question 14: Pain relief in chronic pancreatitis can be obtained by the destruction of: 831 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Celiac plexus block is used for pain relief in chronic pancreatitis as well as pancreatic carcinoma. 
It can be done using alcohol or other analgesics. It is a safe procedure, but the effect is short-lived.

questions.question:
Question 15: A patient with chronic pancreatitis complains of intractable abdominal pain despite the 
administration of analgesics. CT scan shows pancreatic head enlargement. A EUS guided 
fine-needle biopsy ruled out pancreatic malignancy. What will be the preferred management 
in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Beger's procedure is the procedure of choice for patients with chronic pancreatitis, having an 
associated mass in the head of the pancreas. 842 
Sold by @itachibot Beger's procedure is a duodenum-preserving pancreatic head resection. It preserves the function 
of the foregut. Once the pancreatic head is removed, a Roux-en-Y is created and anastomosed to 
the rim of the pancreas or duodenum, pancreatic duct, and body and also the bile duct, if 
involved.

questions.question:
Question 16: A 34-year-old patient presents with intractable pain associated with chronic pancreatitis. 
MRCP shows the chain of lakes appearance. What will be the preferred management in this 
patient?

options.d: Resection of pancreatic tail and pancreatojejunostomy

questions.explanation:
The pancreatic duct dilation observed on pancreatography for chronic pancreatitis is classically 
described as a chain of lakes, which reflects the presence of multiple dilations and stenoses. When it is accompanied by intractable pain, this condition is best treated with side-to-side 
Roux-en-Y pancreaticojejunostomy, also known as the modified Puestow procedure or lateral 
pancreaticojejunostomy.

questions.question:
Question 17: A 36-year-old man presents with dull aching epigastric pain. He gives a history of acute 
abdominal pain following a binge of alcohol 5 weeks back which was managed conservatively. 
On examination, he appears icteric and a firm mass was palpable in the epigastrium. His CT 
scan is given below. Which of the following statements is false about his condition? 832 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: Cyst wall is lined by squamous epithelium.
options.d: Splenic artery is the most common artery involved.

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario with a history of acute pancreatitis, epigastric mass, and the CT image 
showing a cyst is suggestive of pancreatic pseudocyst. The capsule of the cyst is composed of 
collagen and granulation tissue, and it is not lined by epithelium. Hence, it is called a pseudocyst. Pseudocysts are post-inflammatory cysts that arise following an attack of mild acute pancreatitis. 
Formation of a pseudocyst requires 4 weeks or more from the onset of acute pancreatitis. They are 
also the most common complication of chronic pancreatitis. Pseudocysts are usually solitary and most commonly seen in the lesser omental sac. The most 
common artery involved is the splenic artery. Complications of pancreatic pseudocyst include: • Abscess • Systemic sepsis • GI bleeding • Fistula formation • Peritonitis • Obstructive jaundice • Bowel obstruction • Hemorrhage into the cyst • Hemoperitoneum Pancreatic pseudocysts can be distinguished from cystic neoplasms by having high amylase levels 
and absence of mucin and low serum carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) levels. 843 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 18: A young man is incidentally found to have a pseudocyst of the pancreas on abdominal 
ultrasound during a master health check-up. The size of the pseudocyst is 5 cm and is located 
in the tail of the pancreas. Past history is notable for two episodes of acute pancreatitis. How 
will you manage this patient?
questions.explanation:
Observation is the preferred treatment in this case since the size of the pseudocyst is <6 cm and 
is arising from the tail of the pancreas. Indications for conservative management in pancreatic pseudocyst: • Asymptomatic patients • Pseudocysts smaller than 6 cm (according to Bailey) • Located on the tail • No evidence of pancreatic duct obstruction or communication with the main pancreatic duct

questions.question:
Question 19: A 45-year-old patient presents to the emergency room with abdominal pain and severe 
non-bilious vomiting. He was treated for upper abdominal pain 5 weeks ago. CT scan reveals 
a pancreatic pseudocyst of size 8 cm in close proximity to the stomach with secondary 
pressure effects. What is the best treatment option for this patient?
questions.explanation:
The best treatment option for this patient would be to perform a cystogastrostomy since the size 
of the tumor is greater than 6 cm and in close proximity to the stomach. Interventions in pseudocyst are required when: • Complicated by infection • Presence of a mass effect • Diameter increasing in size or greater than 6 cm • Recurrence following the previous resection Endoscopic drainage is usually curative. Surgical drainage is done if endoscopy is contraindicated or has failed. In this cystogastrostomy, an anterior gastrostomy is performed. Once the pseudocyst is located, it 
is drained through the posterior wall of the stomach using a linear stapler. The defect in the 
anterior wall of the stomach is closed in two layers. The image shows the procedure involved in cystogastrostomy. Feature

stomach and nor to the duodenum. This is generally preferred as the last resort as it is associated 
with a lot of complications. Percutaneous drainage to the exterior under radiological guidance is associated with a high 
recurrence rate and high incidence of pancreatic-cutaneous fistula. Hence, it is not usually done.

questions.question:
Question 20: A 55-year-old chronic alcoholic presents with recurrent abdominal pain radiating to the back 
and passage of dark-colored stools. He has pallor and mild epigastric tenderness on 
palpation. Blood investigations show severe anemia and high serum lipase. CT scan reveals a 
pancreatic pseudoaneurysm and subsequent endoscopy shows blood near the ampulla of 
Vater. Identify the false statement about his condition:

options.b: ERCP is the gold standard investigation.
options.c: Coil embolization is done only in stable patients.

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hemosuccus pancreaticus. CT angiography is the gold 
standard in diagnosing hemosuccus pancreaticus. Haemosuccus pancreaticus, also known as pseudohaemobilia, is a rare cause of GI bleeding, due 
to blood originating from the pancreatic duct into the duodenum via the ampulla of Vater. It is 
usually caused by the erosion of a pancreatic pseudocyst into the splenic artery. In hemosuccus pancreatitis, abdominal pain radiating to the back accompanied by melena is the 
most typical presentation. The pain usually has an up and down pattern, which means it changes 
in intensity over time. This is due to the transient closure of pancreatic ducts. Other features 
include: • Hematochezia • Hematemesis • Anemia • Jaundice • A palpable pulsatile mass with a thrill murmur • Retroperitoneal bleeding 845 
Sold by @itachibot Laboratory values show elevated lipase and low hemoglobin levels. The diagnosis is mainly 
through imaging modalities like upper GI endoscopy, ERCP, endoscopic ultrasound (EUS), and 
contrast-enhanced CT scan. CT angiography is the gold standard diagnostic tool. It helps to localize the site of bleed and plan 
the management accordingly. Once the bleeding source is identified, hemodynamically stable patients are managed by coil 
embolization, balloon tamponade, or stent placement. Hemodynamically unstable patients are managed by distal pancreatectomy.

questions.question:
Question 21: Which of the following statements is false about this procedure done for pancreatic 
pseudocyst?

options.a: Failure to respond to an endoscopic treatment is an indication.
options.b: Defect in the anterior wall of the stomach is closed in two layers.
options.c: The pseudocyst is drained through the anterior wall of the stomach.
options.d: Hemorrhage is the major complication expected.

questions.explanation:
The image shows cystogastrostomy, which is done for the pancreatic pseudocyst. The pseudocyst 
is drained through the posterior wall of the stomach. Surgery in pseudocyst is indicated for patients who fail to respond to endoscopic treatment. Pancreatic pseudocysts closely attached to the stomach should be treated with a cystogastrostomy. 
In this procedure, an anterior gastrostomy is performed. Once the pseudocyst is located, it is 
drained through the posterior wall of the stomach using a linear stapler. The defect in the anterior 
wall of the stomach is closed in two layers. Hemorrhage is the major complication expected post-surgery.

questions.question: Question 22: Milwaukee classification is used for the assessment of:
questions.explanation:
Milwaukee classification is used for the assessment of sphincter of Oddi dysfunction. Sphincter of Oddi dysfunction or dyskinesia (SOD) is a clinical syndrome in which pain, 
biochemical abnormalities, and dilatation of the bile duct and/or pancreatic duct are attributed to 
abnormal functions of the sphincter of Oddi. SOD may result from stenosis of the sphincter or from dysmotility. Scarring or stenosis of the 
sphincter can result from the passage of stones, pancreatitis, or prior endoscopic 
sphincterotomies. Milwaukee classification of the sphincter of Oddi dysfunction (SOD) : • Type I SOD is usually managed by Sphincterotomy. Whether such patients should undergo dual 
sphincterotomies (biliary and pancreatic) is debatable. • Type II SOD is usually assessed by a manometry first, followed by surgical or medical 
management based on manometry findings. • Type III SOD is difficult to manage. Surgical management, such as sphincterotomy has variable 
outcomes with response rates ranging from 8% to 65%. Medical management in the form of 
nifedipine, proton-pump inhibitor, botulinum toxin injection, etc. does not have long-term 
benefits as well. Note: 846

questions.question: Question 23: Identify the marked structure:

options.a: It is more common in males
options.b: It only involves the main pancreatic duct
options.c: Head of pancreas is most common site of the neoplasm

questions.explanation:
The structure marked is the main pancreatic duct. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is performed using a side-viewing 
fibreoptic duodenoscope. The ampulla of Vater is intubated, and contrast injected into the biliary 
and pancreatic ducts to display the anatomy radiologically. 847 
Sold by @itachibot ERCP is helpful for: • Direct opacification of bile ducts and pancreatic ducts • Dynamic information during the introduction and drainage of the contrast medium • Visual assessment of the duodenum and ampulla of Vater, thereby facilitating biopsy • Interventional procedures such as sphincterotomy, stone extraction, biliary stenting, and biliary 
stricture dilatation ERCP shows filling of the main pancreatic duct (MPD), common bile duct (B), and gallbladder (G). 
The MPD and CBD drain into the major papillary (large arrow). The small accessory pancreatic 
duct (small arrows) drains separately into the minor papilla (arrowhead). The most common complication of ERCP is acute pancreatitis. The main diagnostic disadvantage 
with ERCP is the underfilling of ducts above a stricture. 848 
Sold by @itachibot Carcinoma Pancreas
